result.text:
Here is one surprisingly elegant equivalent reformulation of the Riemann Hypothesis: Let B be the pointwise maximal function on [0,1] satisfying B(0) = B(1) = 0 and 2B((x+y)/2) ‚â§ B(x) + B(y) + |x - y| for all x and y in [0,1]. Extend it periodically to all the real line.

As Grok correctly notes, this is Takagi function (or blancmange curve), with a fractal-like graph. It is continuous, nowhere differentiable, and less well-known than the Weierstrass function.
 
This function also emerged recently (and independently) in a joint work https://t.co/pgJw9MaEA1  with my student, Natanael Alpay, as a sharp lower bound for the L^1 norm of the square function applied to indicator functions of sets. I was unaware at the time that it is known as the Takagi function or of its connection to the Riemann Hypothesis. Large language models will undoubtedly accelerate scientific discoveries by forging connections across diverse fields of science.

You can easily increase the quality of life for 99.9% of US citizens by properly dealing with the very few well-known repeat "notorious" offenders‚Äîputting them in prison or mental institutions. This is an easy win, and that's a rare thing in the policy world. You do it, then life is immediately better for every citizen.

If your answer is it's morally wrong because of individual rights, then believe me, being in a fully funded institution is far, far better for someone than living on the streets in their own filth, tortured by their inner mental demons, and in constant anguish over who knows what.

Their own families (when they can be found) want this for them as well. That's often why they are out on the streets‚Äîbecause they became too much for their parents/grandparents/brothers/sisters to deal with. 

You're doing nobody any favors, nobody, by letting these people roam the streets in anguish, creating even more anguish.

result.text:
yes, asian and african rivers produce 95% of ocean plastic but nobody asks where the plastic comes from.

plastic recycling is a scam. always has been. 
the industry knew since 1974 it ‚Äúcant be justified economically‚Äù

they funded the recycling campaigns anyway because the alternative was banning plastic.

only 5-6% of US plastic actually gets recycled and europe isnt better. 
the EU exports 1.1 million tonnes of plastic waste per year, 3 million kg leaving every single day. 
31% goes to turkey, 16% to malaysia, 13% to indonesia, all labeled ‚Äúrecyclable‚Äù

most plastics cant even be recycled to begin with (thousands of types, different chemical properties). and for the few that can, the output is lower quality and more toxic than virgin plastic. 
you literally degrade the material each cycle until its worthless.

so what happens to the other 95%? 
western countries ship it to southeast asia and africa under the label ‚Äúrecycling exports‚Äù with the receiving countries promising to recycle it in their stead for a price, but those countries dont have facilities either. so they burn it or dump it in rivers.

every 20 minutes, a 10-tonne truckload of plastic enters the ocean in indonesia alone. 
it may look like indonesians pollute more but that‚Äôs because we ship them our garbage and they have no infrastructure to handle it.

china used to absorb it all. when they banned imports in 2018, the west just redirected to countries with weaker regulations. malaysia, vietnam, philippines. the map below shows the result.

you sort your trash so you feel like youre helping, the plastic goes on a boat, gets burned in a village without emissions controls, poisons their air and water, flows into their rivers, enters the ocean, and in your food and water. 
you feel good about the plastic you recycled and never think about it again but you end up eating it anyway.

then we ban straws and plastic bags and call it environmentalism

items.message:
- The post accurately cites a 2017 Schmidt et al. study estimating 88-95% of riverine plastic entering oceans originates from 10 Asian/African rivers, but reframes this as fallout from Western waste exports, with the EU shipping 1.1 million tonnes annually in 2024‚Äî426,000 tonnes to Turkey and 344,000 to Malaysia alone.
- It exposes plastic recycling as an industry ploy since 1974, when DuPont documents admitted economic infeasibility yet promoted it to avert bans; current US rates hover at 5-9% overall, per 2024 EPA and NIST reports, with recycled material degrading in quality and toxicity.
- Following China's 2018 import ban, redirected exports fueled unmanaged dumping in Southeast Asia, exemplified by Indonesia where environmental analyses report a 10-tonne truckload of plastic entering oceans every 20 minutes, ultimately cycling back into global food chains.

result.text:
I was very late to own a Tesla but among the earliest to try out FSD v14.  It's perhaps the first time I experience an AI that passes the Physical Turing Test: after a long day at work, you press a button, lay back, and couldn't tell if a neural net or a human drove you home.

Despite knowing exactly how robot learning works, I still find it magical watching the steering wheel turn by itself. 

First it feels surreal, next it becomes routine. Then, like the smartphone, taking it away actively hurts. This is how humanity gets rewired and glued to god-like technologies.

The term's real gift: it reveals the default human assumption that life is chess and value can‚Äôt be created‚Äîonly transferred. Once you have the label, you start noticing how often that‚Äôs wrong

items.message:
The Bail Project is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization primarily funded by **private donations from individuals and philanthropic foundations**.

- Its largest source of funding comes from **hundreds of thousands of small individual donors**, with notable surges during events like the 2020 George Floyd protests (e.g., raising around $41‚Äì42 million in 2020 from nearly 468,000 donors).
- It operates a revolving bail fund where donations are used to pay bail, which is typically refunded by courts and reused.
- Institutional support includes grants from **The Audacious Project** (a TED-hosted initiative backed by major philanthropists) and mentions of family foundations like the David Rockefeller Fund.
- Related bail fund networks have received funding from sources like **Open Philanthropy** (funded by Dustin Moskovitz and Cari Tuna) and **MacKenzie Scott**, though these are not directly confirmed for The Bail Project itself.
- The organization does not publicly list specific major donors in detail on its site or annual reports, emphasizing broad community support through monthly "Freedom Funders" and online contributions.

Financial transparency is provided via annual reports and IRS Form 990 filings, showing cumulative bail postings exceeding $91 million as of recent reports, supported entirely by donations (no government funding is prominently mentioned, except isolated past local grants criticized by opponents).

Any USAID funding that had the slightest indication of being spent on worthy causes was continued, but transferred to the State Department.

What they are actually angry about is that most of the USAID funding went not to aid, but to funding far left political causes all around the world, including some of the money coming back to fund the left in America. But they can‚Äôt say that, so they lie instead.
